articles.headline: Before Embracing America-First Agenda, David Perdue Was an Outsourcing Expert
articles.snippet: Mr. Perdue, who faces one of two runoff elections in Georgia that will determine control of the Senate, built a business record that shifted manufacturing and jobs overseas.
articles.abstract: Mr. Perdue, who faces one of two runoff elections in Georgia that will determine control of the Senate, built a business record that shifted manufacturing and jobs overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biographical video from Senator David Perdue’s first campaign, in 2014, celebrated a narrative arc that many fellow Georgians either related to or have aspired to: the story of a humble boy from rural America whose hard work catapulted him into a global business career, navigating free markets and faraway lands, all the while gathering stores of wisdom and wealth.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul, Richard Fausset and Michael LaForgia

articles.headline: States Are Shutting Down Prisons as Guards are Crippled By Covid-19
articles.snippet: States and counties are finding it hard to keep jails and prisons open as the virus ravages both prisoners and staff members. But transferring inmates can spur new outbreaks.
articles.abstract: States and counties are finding it hard to keep jails and prisons open as the virus ravages both prisoners and staff members. But transferring inmates can spur new outbreaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Battered by a wave of coronavirus infections and deaths, local jails and state prison systems around the United States have resorted to a drastic strategy to keep the virus at bay: Shutting down completely and transferring their inmates elsewhere.
articles.byline: By Brendon Derr, Rebecca Griesbach and Danya Issawi

articles.headline: Senate Overrides Trump’s Veto of Defense Bill, Dealing a Legislative Blow
articles.snippet: Republicans joined Democrats to deliver President Trump the first veto override of his presidency in the last days of his term in an overwhelming, bipartisan vote.
articles.abstract: Republicans joined Democrats to deliver President Trump the first veto override of his presidency in the last days of his term in an overwhelming, bipartisan vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Friday voted overwhelmingly to override President Trump’s veto of the annual military policy bill as most Republicans joined Democrats to rebuke Mr. Trump in the final days of his presidency.

articles.headline: In Abrupt Reversal of Iran Strategy, Pentagon Orders Aircraft Carrier Home
articles.snippet: After weeks of escalation and threatening language, the Defense Department is sending mixed messages as the anniversary of the death of an Iranian general nears.
articles.abstract: After weeks of escalation and threatening language, the Defense Department is sending mixed messages as the anniversary of the death of an Iranian general nears.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has abruptly sent the aircraft carrier Nimitz home from the Middle East and Africa over the objections of top military advisers, marking a reversal of a weekslong muscle-flexing strategy aimed at deterring Iran from attacking American troops and diplomats in the Persian Gulf.

articles.headline: As Some Deficit Hawks Turn Dove, the New Politics of Debt Are on Display
articles.snippet: Some Republicans who once scolded about fiscal austerity are now embracing government spending, underlining that the public supports more generous relief.
articles.abstract: Some Republicans who once scolded about fiscal austerity are now embracing government spending, underlining that the public supports more generous relief.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past four years, President Trump and his allies in Congress have all but obliterated the Republican Party’s self-professed commitment to less spending and smaller deficits, pushing policies that have bloated the federal budget deficit to record levels.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Gunfire and Crashing Cars: In Struggling Neighborhoods, ‘We’re Losing Our Grip’
articles.snippet: A year of hardship in parts of Cleveland has left many with the sense that the fabric of their communities was fraying.
articles.abstract: A year of hardship in parts of Cleveland has left many with the sense that the fabric of their communities was fraying.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When evening arrives, Darryl Brazil sits on his porch and watches the world fall apart.

articles.headline: As Understanding of Russian Hacking Grows, So Does Alarm
articles.snippet: Those behind the widespread intrusion into government and corporate networks exploited seams in U.S. defenses and gave away nothing to American monitoring of their systems.
articles.abstract: Those behind the widespread intrusion into government and corporate networks exploited seams in U.S. defenses and gave away nothing to American monitoring of their systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Election Day, General Paul M. Nakasone, the nation’s top cyberwarrior, reported that the battle against Russian interference in the presidential campaign had posted major successes and exposed the other side’s online weapons, tools and tradecraft.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Targeted Killings Are Terrorizing Afghans. And No One Is Claiming Them.
articles.snippet: Most officials believe the Taliban are behind the attacks on civil leaders, but others fear that factions are using chaos as a cover to settle scores, in an echo of Afghanistan’s past civil war.
articles.abstract: Most officials believe the Taliban are behind the attacks on civil leaders, but others fear that factions are using chaos as a cover to settle scores, in an echo of Afghanistan’s past civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A military prosecutor who thought upholding the law was the highest honor, a doctor who inspired her family to study medicine, a journalist who wanted to hold those in power to account and a human-rights activist who sought to combat poverty in her home province: all murdered within weeks by unknown attackers as winter settled over Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Fahim Abed and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Raphael Warnock, From the Pulpit to Politics, Doesn’t Shy From ‘Uncomfortable’ Truths
articles.snippet: He first wanted to run for office years ago. Now Stacey Abrams, the Democratic Party and the Rev. Raphael Warnock all believe that the time is ripe for Georgia voters to send a Black Baptist preacher to Washington.
articles.abstract: He first wanted to run for office years ago. Now Stacey Abrams, the Democratic Party and the Rev. Raphael Warnock all believe that the time is ripe for Georgia voters to send a Black Baptist preacher to Washington.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Mike Baker

articles.headline: Pence Welcomes Futile Bid by G.O.P. Lawmakers to Overturn Election
articles.snippet: Vice President Mike Pence signaled his support as 11 Republican senators and senators-elect said that they would vote to reject President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
articles.abstract: Vice President Mike Pence signaled his support as 11 Republican senators and senators-elect said that they would vote to reject President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence signaled support on Saturday for a futile Republican bid to overturn the election in Congress next week, after 11 Republican senators and senators-elect said that they would vote to reject President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory when the House and Senate meet to formally certify it.

articles.headline: Wall Street Eyes Billions in the Colorado’s Water
articles.snippet: Investor interest in the river could redefine century-old rules for who controls one of the most valuable economic resources in the United States.
articles.abstract: Investor interest in the river could redefine century-old rules for who controls one of the most valuable economic resources in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a myth about water in the Western United States, which is that there is not enough of it. But those who deal closely with water will tell you this is false. There is plenty. It is just in the wrong places.

articles.headline: Will You Pay to Stream Comfort Shows? Discovery Is About to Find Out
articles.snippet: A cable-era way of watching TV comes to streaming with the debut of Discovery+, an on-demand platform with lots of nature shows and cooking programs.
articles.abstract: A cable-era way of watching TV comes to streaming with the debut of Discovery+, an on-demand platform with lots of nature shows and cooking programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Disney+ made its debut, it served up a “Star Wars” blockbuster, “The Mandalorian.” When AppleTV+ came online, it offered a big-budget original series starring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston. Another newcomer to streaming, HBO Max, lured subscribers with a “Wonder Woman” sequel.

articles.headline: A Covid-19 Relief Fund Was Only for Black Residents. Then Came the Lawsuits.
articles.snippet: Oregon earmarked $62 million to explicitly benefit Black individuals and business owners. Now some of the money is in limbo after lawsuits alleging racial discrimination.
articles.abstract: Oregon earmarked $62 million to explicitly benefit Black individuals and business owners. Now some of the money is in limbo after lawsuits alleging racial discrimination.
articles.lead_paragraph: [To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]

articles.headline: ‘A Slap in the Face’: The Pandemic Disrupts Young Oil Careers
articles.snippet: Students and recent graduates struggle to get hired as the oil industry cuts tens of thousands of jobs, some of which may never come back.
articles.abstract: Students and recent graduates struggle to get hired as the oil industry cuts tens of thousands of jobs, some of which may never come back.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Sabrina Burns, a senior at the University of Texas at Austin, had thought she would be launching a lucrative career in the oil and gas industry when she graduated in a few months.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Brandon Thibodeaux

articles.headline: Trump, in Taped Call, Pressured Georgia Official to ‘Find’ Votes to Overturn Election
articles.snippet: The president vaguely warned of a “criminal offense” as he pressured Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger in the call, according to an audio recording.
articles.abstract: The president vaguely warned of a “criminal offense” as he pressured Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger in the call, according to an audio recording.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump pressured Georgia’s Republican secretary of state to “find” him enough votes to overturn the presidential election and vaguely threatened him with “a criminal offense” during an hourlong telephone call on Saturday, according to an audio recording of the conversation.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: Teachers on TV? Schools Try Creative Strategy to Narrow Digital Divide
articles.snippet: It’s another way to reach students without internet or computers during the pandemic.
articles.abstract: It’s another way to reach students without internet or computers during the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly every weekday morning, Valentin Vivar curls up in bed next to his older sister, Araceli, and switches on one of his favorite television shows.

articles.headline: Georgia Is Getting More Blue. The Senate Races Will Tell How Much.
articles.snippet: A reliably red state for almost two decades, Georgia no longer resembles its Deep South neighbors. President Trump and Joe Biden head there Monday to help rally the bases.
articles.abstract: A reliably red state for almost two decades, Georgia no longer resembles its Deep South neighbors. President Trump and Joe Biden head there Monday to help rally the bases.
articles.lead_paragraph: With President Trump touching down in North Georgia on Monday to court white rural voters and President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. rallying support from a diverse electorate in Atlanta, the high-stakes Senate runoffs are concluding with a test of how much the politics have shifted in a state that no longer resembles its Deep South neighbors.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: They Seem to Think the Next Four Years Will Be Normal
articles.snippet: A Beltway school of journalism wants to get back to just-the-facts-ma’am reporting. But how do you cover this Republican Party?
articles.abstract: A Beltway school of journalism wants to get back to just-the-facts-ma’am reporting. But how do you cover this Republican Party?
articles.lead_paragraph: The big debates over political journalism in the Trump years were about morality. What began with arguments over whether the media should call something a “lie” or “racist” has now become: How do you cover a Republican Party that votes to overturn an election?

articles.headline: Republicans Begin New Congress Feuding Over Bid to Overturn Election
articles.snippet: With President Trump ratcheting up his efforts to cling to power, the party has split over whether to back him, posing a major political test.
articles.abstract: With President Trump ratcheting up his efforts to cling to power, the party has split over whether to back him, posing a major political test.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After four years of enabling and appeasing President Trump, Republicans find themselves at the end of his tenure in exactly the place they had so desperately tried to avoid: a toxic internecine brawl over his conduct and character that could badly damage their party.

articles.headline: Hundreds of Google Employees Unionize, Culminating Years of Activism
articles.snippet: The creation of the union, a rarity in Silicon Valley, follows years of increasing outspokenness by Google workers. Executives have struggled to handle the change.
articles.abstract: The creation of the union, a rarity in Silicon Valley, follows years of increasing outspokenness by Google workers. Executives have struggled to handle the change.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — More than 400 Google engineers and other workers have formed a union, the group revealed on Monday, capping years of growing activism at one of the world’s largest companies and presenting a rare beachhead for labor organizers in staunchly anti-union Silicon Valley.
